Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; well-modelled, high-rounded back, with clypeus, prothorax and elytra indicated by single incised lines, notches for humeral callosities and one triangle at junction of elytra and prothorax division; legs carefully modelled with undercut triangle at side and feathering round front; underside incised with representation of a triton, compound Greek mythical animal, with horse forepart and two forelegs, back legs trailing underneath, wings, fish body and tail; pierced longitudinally; in greyish blue paste of hard texture; worn surface.
Curator's comments: Hellenizing motifs, such as the triton depicted on this scarab, are popular on scarabs produced at Naukratis (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). The scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in Sardinia, south Italy, Carthage, Perachora and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 127-128, type XXXV, subtype 1-7, see especially 6 for this piece). Cerveteri and Tarento provide good parallels to this motif (Hölbl 1979, pl. 74, 3a, no.111 and pl. 137, 1a, no. 1171). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hölbl, G. 1979, Beziehungen der ägyptischen Kultur zu Altitalien (EPRO 62), Leiden. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 147)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 127-128, type XXXV 6)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.22) (phase 3)
